title: One pipe can fill a tank in hours. Another pipe can filled the tank in 6 hours. Starting with an empty tank, if we turn on both pipes, how many hours will it take to fill the tank? - Quora

response.answer_text: To solve this problem we must find the fill rate of each pipe in ltr/hr or gals/hr (whatever we are working in), add those 2 together then devide the result into the capacity of the tank. In our problem we only know one variable, the time it takes one pipe to fill the tank. Let's define some place holders for the unknown entries… Tank capacity = c Time to fill tank by first pipe = p Fill rate for first pipe = c/p Fill rate for second pipe = c/6 So total fill rate = c/p + c/6 = (pc + 6c)/6p Now we need to devide c by the fill rate… c/((pc + 6c)/6p)) = 6cp/pc+6c Time taken to fill tank is 6cp/pc+6c where c is tank capacity and p is time for the first pipe to fill the tank. Mal.

If one pipe can fill the tank in x hours, 1/x part of the tank is filled in 1 hour and if another pipe can fill the tank in 6 hours, 1/6 of the tank can be filled in 1 hour. Filling together in 1 hour, they can fill, 1/t part of the tank in 1 hour: 1/x+1/6=1/t; (6+x)/6x=1/t; (6+x)t=6x(1)=6x; (6+x)t=6x; t=6x/(6+x) number hours for both pipes to finish filling the tank
